standard_metadata.standard_description: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Create division equations with area models

question.content: Jerry split up the area of a rectangle to help him solve a division equation.    **What division equation did Jerry solve?**

images.alt: area model split into 4 parts, each with a width of 6 units. From top to bottom the parts have a height of 100 units and an area of 600 square units; a height of 20 units and an area of 120 square units; a height of 4 units and an area of 24 square units; an unlabeled height and an area of 2 square units

hints.content: $\redE{\text{total area}}\div \tealE{\text{width}} = \maroonD{\text{height}}$
To find the area of the entire rectangle, we need to add the areas of the smaller rectangles that make it up.  $\purpleD{600}+\blueE{120}+\greenE{24}+\goldE{2}=\redE{746}$
The area of the entire rectangle is $\redE{746}$ square units.

images.alt: the same model with the combined area labeled 746 square units and the height labeled question mark units

hints.content: Jerry is dividing the area of the entire rectangle by $\tealE{6}$.    To find the total height, we add each of the smaller heights. We know three of the heights.  $100+20+4=\maroonD{124}$   The leftover smaller rectangle has an area of $\goldE{2}$ square units. That is less than $\tealE{6}$, so it is Jerry's remainder.
Jerry was solving the equation $\redE{746} \div \tealE{6} =\maroonD{124}$ remainder $\goldE{2}$.

question.content: Aria split up the area of a rectangle to help her solve a division equation.    **What equation did Aria solve?**

images.alt: area model split into 4 parts, each with a width of 2 units. From top to bottom the parts have a height of 4,000 units and an area of 8,000 square units; a height of 150 units and an area of 300 square units; a height of 1 unit and an area of 2 square units; an unlabeled height and an area of 1 square units.

hints.content: $\redE{\text{total area}}\div \tealE{\text{width}} = \maroonD{\text{height}}$
To find the area of the entire rectangle, we need to add the areas of the smaller rectangles that make it up.  $\purpleD{8{,}000}+\blueE{300}+\greenE{2}+\goldE{1}=\redE{8{,}303}$
The area of the entire rectangle is $\redE{8{,}303}$ square units.

images.alt: the same model with the combined area labeled 8,303 square units and the height labeled question mark units

hints.content: Aria is dividing the area of the entire rectangle by $\tealE{2}$.    To find the total height, we add each of the smaller heights. We know three of the heights.  $4{,}000+150+1=\maroonD{4{,}151}$   The leftover smaller rectangle has an area of $\goldE{1}$ square unit. That is less than $\tealE{2}$, so it is Aria's remainder.
Aria was solving the equation $\redE{8{,}303} \div \tealE{2} =\maroonD{4{,}151}$ remainder $\goldE{1}$.

hints.content: Amit is dividing the area of the entire rectangle by $\tealE{7}$.    To find the total height, we add each of the smaller heights. We know three of the heights.  $100+20+6=\maroonD{126}$   The leftover smaller rectangle has an area of $\goldE{5}$ square units. That is less than $\tealE{7}$, so it is Amit's remainder.
Amit was solving the equation $\redE{887} \div \tealE{7} =\maroonD{126}$ remainder $\goldE{5}$.

question.content: Carlos split up the area of a rectangle to help him solve a division equation.    **What equation did Carlos solve?**

images.alt: area model split into 4 parts, each with a width of 5 units. From top to bottom the parts have a height of 100 units and an area of 500 square units; a height of 20 units and an area of 100 square units; a height of 10 units and an area of 50 square units; a height of 9 units and an area of 45 square units.

hints.content: $\redE{\text{total area}}\div \tealE{\text{width}} = \maroonD{\text{height}}$
To find the area of the entire rectangle, we need to add the areas of the smaller rectangles that make it up.  $\purpleD{500}+\blueE{100}+\greenE{50}+\goldE{45}=\redE{695}$
The area of the entire rectangle is $\redE{695}$ square units.

images.alt: the same model with the combined area labeled 695 square units and the height labeled question mark units

hints.content: Carlos is dividing the area of the entire rectangle by $\tealE{5}$.    To find the total height, we add each of the smaller heights.  $100+20+10+9=\maroonD{139}$  There is no leftover, so the remainder is $\goldE{0}$.
Carlos was solving the equation $\redE{695} \div \tealE{5} =\maroonD{139}$ remainder $\goldE{0}$.

question.content: Manco split up the area of a rectangle to help him solve a division equation.    **What equation did Manco solve?**

images.alt: area model split into 2 parts, each with a width of 9 units. From top to bottom the parts have a height of 100 units and an area of 900 square units; a height of 7 units and an area of 63 square units.

hints.content: $\redE{\text{total area}}\div \tealE{\text{width}} = \maroonD{\text{height}}$
To find the area of the entire rectangle, we need to add the areas of the smaller rectangles that make it up.  $\purpleD{900}+\blueE{63}=\redE{963}$
The area of the entire rectangle is $\redE{963}$ square units.

images.alt: the same model with the combined area labeled 963 square units and the height labeled question mark units

hints.content: Manco is dividing the area of the entire rectangle by $\tealE{9}$.    To find the total height, we add each of the smaller heights.  $100+7=\maroonD{107}$  There is no leftover, so there is no remainder.
Manco was solving the equation $\redE{963} \div \tealE{9} =\maroonD{107}$.

question.content: Li Na split up the area of a rectangle to help her solve a division equation.    **What equation did Li Na solve?**

From top to bottom the parts have a height of 500 units and an area of 2,000 square units; a height of 100 units and an area of 400 square units; a height of 80 units and an area of 320 square units; a height of 3 units and an area of 12 square units.

hints.content: $\redE{\text{total area}}\div \tealE{\text{width}} = \maroonD{\text{height}}$
To find the area of the entire rectangle, we need to add the areas of the smaller rectangles that make it up.  $\purpleD{2{,}000}+\blueE{400}+\greenE{320}+\goldE{12}=\redE{2{,}732}$
The area of the entire rectangle is $\redE{2{,}732}$ square units.

images.alt: the same model with the combined area labeled 2,732 square units and the height labeled question mark units

hints.content: Li Na is dividing the area of the entire rectangle by $\tealE{4}$.    To find the total height, we add each of the smaller heights.  $500+100+80+3=\maroonD{683}$  There is no leftover, so there is no remainder.
Li Na was solving the equation $\redE{2{,}732} \div \tealE{4} =\maroonD{683}$.

question.content: Melissa split up the area of a rectangle to help her solve a division equation.    **What equation did Melissa solve?**

images.alt: area model split into 4 parts, each with a width of 4 units. From top to bottom the parts have a height of 1,000 units and an area of 4,000 square units; a height of 25 units and an area of 100 square units; a height of 3 units and an area of 12 square units; an unlabeled height and an area of 3 square units.

hints.content: $\redE{\text{total area}}\div \tealE{\text{width}} = \maroonD{\text{height}}$
To find the area of the entire rectangle, we need to add the areas of the smaller rectangles that make it up.  $\purpleD{4{,}000}+\blueE{100}+\greenE{12}+\goldE{3}=\redE{4{,}115}$
The area of the entire rectangle is $\redE{4{,}115}$ square units.

images.alt: the same model with the combined area labeled 4,115 square units and the height labeled question mark units

hints.content: Melissa is dividing the area of the entire rectangle by $\tealE{4}$.    To find the total height, we add each of the smaller heights. We know three of the heights.  $1{,}000+25+3=\maroonD{1{,}028}$   The leftover smaller rectangle has an area of $\goldE{3}$ square units. That is less than $\tealE{4}$, so it is Melissa's remainder.
Melissa was solving the equation $\redE{4{,}115} \div \tealE{4} =\maroonD{1{,}028}$ remainder $\goldE{3}$.
